image.altText: A ute in burnt out surroundings on the side of a road.

items.synopsis: More hot, dry and windy conditions are expected to challenge fire crews today, but potential danger of a different kind is causing concern elsewhere in the state.

items.synopsis: Experts say capacity on regional and international flights have not returned to pre-pandemic levels and are keeping airfares high.

title.children: Flight prices still remain high after COVID, but some tickets are much more expensive than others

title.children: Dangerous wind, heavy rain, flooding forecast to hit eastern states as intense storm system deepens

image.altText: Clare O'Neil speaks at a press conference inside parliament house

items.synopsis: The federal government says criminals have been allowed to exploit Australia's visa system for human trafficking and other organised crime, as it announces a boost in compliance officers and new rules for migration agents.

title.children: Government launches crackdown on 'criminals' exploiting visa system

image.altText: Heather Wilkinson smiles, dressed in a warm red cardigan, standing in front of greenery.

items.synopsis: Heather Wilkinson, who died after a suspected mushroom poisoning incident in Victoria, is remembered by her son as being thoughtful, faithful and full of grace at a public memorial service.

title.children: Mushroom poisoning victim remembered as devoted Christian at memorial service

image.altText: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk delivers here CEDA State of the State address.

items.synopsis: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk is delivering her annual State of the State address. Follow the live updates.

title.children: Cost of living crisis 'hurting families that can least afford it', Queensland premier says

image.altText: A woman looks directly at camera.

items.synopsis: Thousands of Australians opted to do their grocery shopping online during the pandemic, but plenty are yet to return to shopping in store as they try to get the most bang for their buck amid the high cost of living.

title.children: Sarah does 90 per cent of her grocery shopping online — but she's not checking out at the big supermarkets

image.altText: Pat Conroy Henry Puna

items.synopsis: The Pacific's top diplomat says Australia's credibility in the region will be bolstered if the nation votes in favour of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament on October 14.

title.children: Yes referendum outcome could bolster Australia's standing, Pacfic diplomat says

image.altText: flooding in Sale

items.synopsis: Heavy rain in Victoria brings some relief to firefighters, but residents now face the threat of flash flooding, as emergency services respond to 300 calls for help.

title.children: Victorian towns welcome downpour after bushfires, but now face flood threat

image.altText: A street painted various shades of green with concrete benches and large metal shade structures.

items.synopsis: Work on a street beautification project in Central West NSW started less than a year ago, but the local council last night voted to rip it out and replace it with car parks.

title.children: City council votes to demolish $1.6 million beautification project for car parks

image.altText: group of indigenous men standing

items.synopsis: Since 2000, the rate of Indigenous Australians imprisoned has risen eight times that of non-Indigenous Australians. There are hopes a Voice to Parliament will help reverse that trend.

title.children: Australia has one of the highest Indigenous incarceration rates in the world. Could a Voice to Parliament change that?

image.altText: A bald man in a Hawaiian shirt standing in front of a tree.

items.synopsis: Gold Coast man Ashley Paul Griffith, 45, is facing more than 1,600 child sex offences stemming from a major Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigation.

title.children: Identity of former childcare worker charged with sexually abusing 91 children revealed under new Queensland laws

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in Voice referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kirstie Wellauer Indigenous Communities TV journalist Steve Hodder Watt has been visiting remote communities in Central Australia over the past week and says there has been poor communication at remote polling booths in Yuendumu, Yuelamu and Laramba. "Some of the responses were that there wasn't much awareness if any about the early polling or early voting happening in the communities." The Australian Electoral Commission committed to expanding resources in remote communities for the referendum. Hodder Watt says a lack of signage, translators and low foot traffic at some of the booths meant many community members weren't aware that voting was underway. "It really was left up to community members and organisations on the day to make people aware," he said. "There is a risk there that some people would have missed out."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indigenous journalist says remote voting hampered by lack of signage and local translators at some remote polls

props.alt: A man sits down while wearing a cap.

children.content: Steve Hodder Watt says there has been poor communication at some remote polling booths.
(ABC)
Reporting by Kirstie Wellauer
Indigenous Communities TV journalist
Steve Hodder Watt
has been visiting remote communities in
Central Australia
over the past week and says there has been poor communication at remote polling booths in
Yuendumu
Yuelamu
and
Laramba.
"Some of the responses were that there wasn't much awareness if any about the early polling or early voting happening in the communities."
The
Australian Electoral Commission
committed to expanding resources in remote communities for the referendum.
Hodder Watt says a lack of signage, translators and low foot traffic at some of the booths meant many community members weren't aware that voting was underway.
"It really was left up to community members and organisations on the day to make people aware," he said.
"There is a risk there that some people would have missed out."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Rebecca Brice No campaigners have visited a pre-polling booth in Adelaide's eastern suburbs, including Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price. She joined federal Liberal colleagues at the Marden polling booth and held an impromptu press conference, saying she believes exit polls are under-representing No votes. "There are those that are reluctant to express a public vote for No. "Really, if we were to take people's true measure of how they actually voted, we would probably find that there were more people voting No than actually those who have come out to say publicly." Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price plans to cast her ballot in her home town next week. The Marden polling booth is in the federal electorate of Sturt and the local Liberal MP James Stevens says how people vote there will be crucial. "If Sturt votes No, South Australia will vote No and if South Australia votes No the referendum will be defeated, so we take our responsibility here on the ground very seriously."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Jacinta  Nampijinpa Price visits voting booth in Adelaide

props.alt: A woman in a jacket stands while smiling with a man in  a jacket.

children.content: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price visited a pre-polling booth on Wednesday.
(ABC:  Anisha Pillarisetty)

"Really, if we were to take people's true measure of how they actually voted, we would probably find that there were more people voting No than actually those who have come out to say publicly."
Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price plans to cast her ballot in her home town next week.
The Marden polling booth is in the federal electorate of
Sturt
and the local
Liberal MP James Stevens
says how people vote there will be crucial.
"If Sturt votes No, South Australia will vote No and if South Australia votes No the referendum will be defeated, so we take our responsibility here on the ground very seriously."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As I mentioned earlier, the prime minister says more than 600,000 Australians have voted early. Early referendum voting opened across the country this week. You can find an early polling location near you using the AEC's 'Where Can I Vote?' tool. Below are the reasons why you can vote early in the Voice referendum: You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote You are more than 8km from a polling place You are travelling You can't leave your workplace to vote You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is) You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained You are a silent elector You have a reasonable fear for your safety You can read more about whether you are eligible to vote early here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How to vote early in the Voice referendum

featuredLink.title: Here's how to vote early in the referendum and who's eligible

props.alt: Five people have their heads down and backs towards the camera looking at a piece of paper.

children.content: Early voting has kicked off around the country.
(ABC Gippsland: Kerrin Thomas)
As I mentioned earlier, the
prime minister
says more than
600,000 Australians have voted early
Early referendum voting opened across the country this week.
You can find an early polling location near you using the
AEC's 'Where Can I Vote?' tool.
Below are the reasons why you can
vote early
in the Voice referendum:
You are outside the electorate where you are enrolled to vote
You are more than 8km from a polling place
You are travelling
You can't leave your workplace to vote
You are seriously ill, infirm or due to give birth shortly (or are caring for someone who is)
You are a patient in hospital and can't vote at the hospital
You have religious beliefs that prevent you from attending a polling place
You are in prison serving a sentence of less than three years or otherwise detained
You are a silent elector
You have a reasonable fear for your safety
You can read more about whether you are eligible to vote early here.

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A composite image of an older man with white hair, and a cream brick building with an ornate veranda.

items.synopsis: William Arnott emigrated from Scotland in the 1840s and went on to build a biscuit empire in his new homeland. His first bakehouse in Morpeth is still operating, but it's not biscuits coming out of the woodfired oven these days.

title.children: It's 175 years since William Arnott first made biscuits in this small-town bakery — and it's still running today

image.altText: Barbed wire on the fence at Don Dale

title.children: Years after a royal commission called for its closure, why is Don Dale still used to detain children?

image.altText: A speed sign on the side of a country road. Its numerals have been altered with tape so that it reads "No".

items.synopsis: Speed signs altered to read "No" have been spotted in SA, sparking safety concerns and a police investigation.
